Has anyone read this? The reason I put this thread in here is because it is related to philosophy.. I have to read it for my AP European History course, so what I'm wondering is, how good is it? I've read maybe 10 pages and find it interesting from a historical and philosophical perspective, but incredibly unrealistic when it comes down to the actual actions that occur within the book.
I tried reading it. It's about as philosophically interesting as Dianetics. Maybe that's just my analytic bias showing.

I read it a few years ago and found it quite interesting. The plot isn't meant to be realistic. It's a framework from which to launch discussions of various philosophies, and later in the book is used as an example of a philosophy. The presentations of the various philosophies were clear and interesting, and as far as I recall fairly accurate. All in all I'd call it an interesting and accesible introduction to philosophy.

I'm reading it at the moment, as a way to get an overview of the development of philosophy. Unfortunately, I have my "reading for content" mode and my "reading for pleasure" mode, and they aren't mixing too well. Its a good concept though, and probably much more accesible than a short introduction book or something.

Early on I found the plot between the philosophy less interesting. Later on it becomes much better and more important. I would reccomend it.
 
 It's a very broad overview, but that's very useful sometimes.

A better book is a textbook called "Archetypes of Wisdom: An Introduction to Philosophy" by Douglas Soccio. You can just flip it open to a random page and find interesting and well-presented introductory material for philosophy. One of the nice things about it are the quotes and definitions that line the margins.
